desc: The SPRED1 gene encodes a member of the Sprouty family of proteins. SPRED1 is a negative regulator of the MAP-kinase (MAPK) pathway (PMID: 15683364, 21364986). The mechanism by which SPRED1 inhibits MAPK signaling involves NF1 (neurofibromatosis type 1), which, upon interaction with SPRED1, localizes to the plasma membrane and facilitates RAS inactivation (PMID: 22751498, 26635368). Overexpression of SPRED1 in a hepatocellular carcinoma model leads to a decrease in cell motility and an increase in the expression of metalloproteinases, which are involved in invasion and metastasis (PMID: 16652141). SPRED1 is rarely mutated in cancers (cBioPortal, MSKCC, Dec. 2016). However, germline loss-of-function mutations in SPRED1 are the cause of Legius syndrome, a familial disorder with neurofibromatosis-like features (PMID: 24334617, 17704776, 19366998).
articles/0/title: Germline loss-of-function mutations in SPRED1 cause a neurofibromatosis 1-like phenotype.
articles/1/title: Legius syndrome, an Update. Molecular pathology of mutations in SPRED1.
articles/1/reference: Brems H et al. The Keio journal of medicine. 2013;62(4)107-12.
articles/2/title: SPRED1 germline mutations caused a neurofibromatosis type 1 overlapping phenotype.
articles/3/title: Spreds, inhibitors of the Ras/ERK signal transduction, are dysregulated in human hepatocellular carcinoma and linked to the malignant phenotype of tumors.
articles/4/title: A shared molecular mechanism underlies the human rasopathies Legius syndrome and Neurofibromatosis-1.
articles/5/title: Sprouty2 and Spred1-2 proteins inhibit the activation of the ERK pathway elicited by cyclopentenone prostanoids.
articles/6/title: Interaction between a Domain of the Negative Regulator of the Ras-ERK Pathway, SPRED1 Protein, and the GTPase-activating Protein-related Domain of Neurofibromin Is Implicated in Legius Syndrome and Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
articles/7/title: Distinct requirements for the Sprouty domain for functional activity of Spred proteins.

desc: SPRED1, a negative regulator of the MAP-kinase pathway, is mutated at low frequencies in various cancers.
